BIOS211
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
This module is about the parasites and pathogens that normally infect wild animals and plants and which cause disease in
people and livestock. The module will consider the different types of parasites and pathogens; how, when, and where they
infect hosts; the evolution (and co-evolution) of parasites and hosts, and host responses and adaptation to infection. The
module is taught through lectures and workshops, giving students the opportunity to discuss concepts and practice problem solving. The assessment consists of producing a poster (or equivalent) on an example parasite or pathogen and a Briefing Note on a real-world infection scenario.
Educational Aims
1. To develop students’ understanding of the biology of parasites and pathogens and their interaction with hosts, and host responses to infection.

2. To raise students’ awareness of the importance of infection in animal and plant biology and its relevance to disease in people, livestock and crops.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module is about the parasites and pathogens that normally infect wild animals and plants and which cause disease in
people and livestock. The module will consider the different types of parasites and pathogens; how, when, and where they
infect hosts; the evolution (and co-evolution) of parasites and hosts, and host responses and adaptation to infection. The
module is taught through lectures and workshops, giving students the opportunity to discuss concepts and practice
problem solving. The assessment consists of producing a poster (or equivalent) on an example parasite or pathogen and a
Briefing Note on a real-world infection scenario.
Outline Syllabus
This module introduces students to a core feature of animal and plant life – being infected by parasites and pathogens, and that such infection is the normal state, and as such infection is a major evolutionary and ecological force. The module will consider the full range of parasites and pathogens, but will use key examples of very-well studied infections of people and livestock. The main themes of this module are:

1. The different types of micro-parasites (viruses, bacteria, fungi, protozoa) and macro-parasites (platyhelminthes, nematodes, arthropods) as ecto- and endo-parasites,
and their routes of transmission among hosts.

2. The adaptations of parasites and pathogens for an infection lifestyle.

3. The responses of hosts to being infected with parasites and pathogens, and the effects of infection on host fitness.

4. The evolution of parasites, and the co-evolution of parasites and their hosts, and the evolution of parasite virulence.

5. The patterns of distribution of parasites and pathogens in host populations and how this is related to parasite transmission, and to seeking to control infection in host populations.

6. Examples of key infections of people and of livestock and approaches to their control.
Teaching and Learning Methods
The module will be taught via a mixture of lectures and workshops (typically 2 lectures and 1 workshop each week). Learning and teaching throughout this module is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching). Students will have access to online materials including discussion boards, videos, slides and websites (digital literacy). Lectures will be recorded to enable students to access the material remotely (inclusivity). Students will be encouraged to connect their course-based learning with wider reports of relevance, such as continuing human and animal infections across the globe and reports of new therapies and treatments and
to understand this with the broader infection context.

Teaching Method 1
Lectures:
These will cover the core module content.
Attendance Record: Yes

Teaching Method 2
Workshops:
Structured discussion and / or problem-solving workshops will be used to deepen students’ understanding of the topics and to integrate different levels of understanding of infection biology
Attendance Recorded: Yes

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability and organisational skills.

Liverpool Curriculum and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. This module contributes to programmes which are specifically designed to support students for future careers in Biosciences:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists in the field of microbiology and infection biology to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with evidence-based publications of recent clinical and scientific research and application-based sessions/workshops, which highlights how practical skills in microbiology and infection biology research inform biotechnological advancement, therapeutic strategies and management of disease.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Self-directed learning, using interactive resources will allow students to prepare for sessions and gain understanding of practical elements before attending. Resource templates use accessible design schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Negotiated assessment.

Active learning: Continual feedback provided to students by staff, demonstrators and peers alike allow students to assess the extent of their learning and continually develop. Collaborative discussion and interpretation of practical methods and their application to wider science fosters deeper learning. Furthermore, group working in diverse groupings allow students to gain insights into broader perspectives

Authentic assessment: There are two assessment components. The poster or equivalent assessment requires students to lead their own enquiry to select, appraise and concisely communicate specialist subject knowledge in a digestible manner for different target demographics in a medium of their choice. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning and inclusivity. Written scientific assessment, in the form of a briefing note is highly authentic and requires students to understand and integrate different aspects of parasite and pathogen biology and apply this to a real-world infection scenario.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. Workshops involve collaborative groupwork and experimental learning. Learners work as part of a team to plan and carry out complex technical work, under expert supervision. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise. Successfully completing a practical session builds confidence in technical skills.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Learners have access to advanced digital resources, programmes and analytical tools that will assist in the undertaking of data analyses. These are used as part of both lab based practical analyses and independent learning to consolidate practical and theoretical knowledge. Digital technology is embedded into practical teaching with the use of experimental applications, methodologies and practices that learners can explore in their own time. Assessment activity also required students to develop competency with digital technology in order to effectively analyse data, communicate findings and present ideas/concepts.

Global citizenship: Biosciences is a globally connected professional community. Learning and assessment activities embed values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation and use scientific cases of diverse and underrepresented communities, focus on sustainable practices within the lab and field environment, whilst focusing on wider international collaboration in order to achieve goals. There is a strong ethical focus within the school that empowers learners to take personal responsibility for human impact of their actions, with focus on practical related ethics..

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
This module will be assessed by two pieces of coursework. The first assessment (worth 40% of the module) is a poster format (or equivalent) focussed on an example parasite or pathogen from the first half of the module, which the student will choose (which contributes to inclusivity) with staff supervision. This can be a traditional paper poster, or an electronic poster, or a static video installation, or a YouTube-style video, etc. The teaching team will develop these options as this module progresses, and as technology and students’ interests develop.

The second assessment (worth 60%) is in the format of a Briefing Note on a real-world relevant infection scenario, which will require students to understand and integrate different aspects of parasite and pathogen biology and apply this to a real-world setting, which is an authentic assessment.

As mentioned above, both assessments are authentic:
The poster or equivalent assessment requires students to lead their own enquiry to select, appraise and concisely communicate specialist subject knowledge in a digestible manner for different target demographics in a medium of their choice. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning and inclusivity. Written scientific assessment, in the form of a briefing note is highly authentic and requires students to understand and integrate different aspects of parasite and pathogen biology and apply this to a real-world infection scenario.

Formative Feedback will be provided in the weekly workshop sessions and in this way for the assessed material. Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Resit strategy: Resit opportunity will be given to the assessments specified where a resit is available. The resit will have similar format and content as the original assessment, but with substantial revision required and will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 40% (pass mark).

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details of the assessments are in the table below.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that are deemed necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

This module contributes to programmes which are specifically designed to support students for future careers in Biosciences:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists in the field of microbiology and infection biology to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with evidence-based publications of recent clinical and scientific research and application-based sessions/workshops, which highlights how practical skills in microbiology and infection biology research inform biotechnological advancement, therapeutic strategies and management of disease.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Self-directed learning, using interactive resources will allow students to prepare for sessions and gain understanding of practical elements before attending. Resource templates use accessible design schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Negotiated assessment.

Active learning: Continual feedback provided to students by staff, demonstrators and peers alike allow students to assess the extent of their learning and continually develop. Collaborative discussion and interpretation of practical methods and their application to wider science fosters deeper learning. Furthermore, group working in diverse groupings allow students to gain insights into broader perspectives

Authentic assessment: There are two assessment components. The poster or equivalent assessment requires students to lead their own enquiry to select, appraise and concisely communicate specialist subject knowledge in a digestible manner for different target demographics in a medium of their choice. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning and inclusivity. Written scientific assessment, in the form of a briefing note is highly authentic and requires students to understand and integrate different aspects of parasite and pathogen biology and apply this to a real-world infection scenario.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. Workshops involve collaborative groupwork and experimental learning. Learners work as part of a team to plan and carry out complex technical work, under expert supervision. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise. Successfully completing a practical session builds confidence in technical skills.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Learners have access to advanced digital resources, programmes and analytical tools that will assist in the undertaking of data analyses. These are used as part of both lab based practical analyses and independent learning to consolidate practical and theoretical knowledge. Digital technology is embedded into practical teaching with the use of experimental applications, methodologies and practices that learners can explore in their own time. Assessment activity also required students to develop competency with digital technology in order to effectively analyse data, communicate findings and present ideas/concepts.

Global citizenship: Biosciences is a globally connected professional community. Learning and assessment activities embed values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation and use scientific cases of diverse and underrepresented communities, focus on sustainable practices within the lab and field environment, whilst focusing on wider international collaboration in order to achieve goals. There is a strong ethical focus within the school that empowers learners to take personal responsibility for human impact of their actions, with focus on practical related ethics..

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
This module will be assessed by two pieces of coursework. The first assessment (worth 40% of the module) is a poster format (or equivalent) focussed on an example parasite or pathogen from the first half of the module, which the student will choose (which contributes to inclusivity) with staff supervision. This can be a traditional paper poster, or an electronic poster, or a static video installation, or a YouTube-style video, etc. The teaching team will develop these options as this module progresses, and as technology and students’ interests develop.

The second assessment (worth 60%) is in the format of a Briefing Note on a real-world relevant infection scenario, which will require students to understand and integrate different aspects of parasite and pathogen biology and apply this to a real-world setting, which is an authentic assessment.

As mentioned above, both assessments are authentic:
The poster or equivalent assessment requires students to lead their own enquiry to select, appraise and concisely communicate specialist subject knowledge in a digestible manner for different target demographics in a medium of their choice. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning and inclusivity. Written scientific assessment, in the form of a briefing note is highly authentic and requires students to understand and integrate different aspects of parasite and pathogen biology and apply this to a real-world infection scenario.

Formative Feedback will be provided in the weekly workshop sessions and in this way for the assessed material. Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Resit strategy: Resit opportunity will be given to the assessments specified where a resit is available. The resit will have similar format and content as the original assessment, but with substantial revision required and will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 40% (pass mark).

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details of the assessments are in the table below.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that are deemed necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
This module is about the parasites and pathogens that normally infect wild animals and plants and which cause disease in
people and livestock. The module will consider the different types of parasites and pathogens; how, when, and where they
infect hosts; the evolution (and co-evolution) of parasites and hosts, and host responses and adaptation to infection. The
module is taught through lectures and workshops, giving students the opportunity to discuss concepts and practice problem solving. The assessment consists of producing a poster (or equivalent) on an example parasite or pathogen and a Briefing Note on a real-world infection scenario.
Educational Aims
1. To develop students’ understanding of the biology of parasites and pathogens and their interaction with hosts, and host responses to infection.

2. To raise students’ awareness of the importance of infection in animal and plant biology and its relevance to disease in people, livestock and crops.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module is about the parasites and pathogens that normally infect wild animals and plants and which cause disease in
people and livestock. The module will consider the different types of parasites and pathogens; how, when, and where they
infect hosts; the evolution (and co-evolution) of parasites and hosts, and host responses and adaptation to infection. The
module is taught through lectures and workshops, giving students the opportunity to discuss concepts and practice
problem solving. The assessment consists of producing a poster (or equivalent) on an example parasite or pathogen and a
Briefing Note on a real-world infection scenario.
Outline Syllabus
This module introduces students to a core feature of animal and plant life – being infected by parasites and pathogens, and that such infection is the normal state, and as such infection is a major evolutionary and ecological force. The module will consider the full range of parasites and pathogens, but will use key examples of very-well studied infections of people and livestock. The main themes of this module are:

1. The different types of micro-parasites (viruses, bacteria, fungi, protozoa) and macro-parasites (platyhelminthes, nematodes, arthropods) as ecto- and endo-parasites,
and their routes of transmission among hosts.

2. The adaptations of parasites and pathogens for an infection lifestyle.

3. The responses of hosts to being infected with parasites and pathogens, and the effects of infection on host fitness.

4. The evolution of parasites, and the co-evolution of parasites and their hosts, and the evolution of parasite virulence.

5. The patterns of distribution of parasites and pathogens in host populations and how this is related to parasite transmission, and to seeking to control infection in host populations.

6. Examples of key infections of people and of livestock and approaches to their control.
Teaching and Learning Methods
The module will be taught via a mixture of lectures and workshops (typically 2 lectures and 1 workshop each week). Learning and teaching throughout this module is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching). Students will have access to online materials including discussion boards, videos, slides and websites (digital literacy). Lectures will be recorded to enable students to access the material remotely (inclusivity). Students will be encouraged to connect their course-based learning with wider reports of relevance, such as continuing human and animal infections across the globe and reports of new therapies and treatments and
to understand this with the broader infection context.

Teaching Method 1
Lectures:
These will cover the core module content.
Attendance Record: Yes

Teaching Method 2
Workshops:
Structured discussion and / or problem-solving workshops will be used to deepen students’ understanding of the topics and to integrate different levels of understanding of infection biology
Attendance Recorded: Yes

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability and organisational skills.

Liverpool Curriculum and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. This module contributes to programmes which are specifically designed to support students for future careers in Biosciences:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists in the field of microbiology and infection biology to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research evidence. Assessment Strategy
This module will be assessed by two pieces of coursework. The first assessment (worth 40% of the module) is a poster format (or equivalent) focussed on an example parasite or pathogen from the first half of the module, which the student will choose (which contributes to inclusivity) with staff supervision. This can be a traditional paper poster, or an electronic poster, or a static video installation, or a YouTube-style video, etc. The teaching team will develop these options as this module progresses, and as technology and students’ interests develop.

The second assessment (worth 60%) is in the format of a Briefing Note on a real-world relevant infection scenario, which will require students to understand and integrate different aspects of parasite and pathogen biology and apply this to a real-world setting, which is an authentic assessment.

This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning and inclusivity. Written scientific assessment, in the form of a briefing note is highly authentic and requires students to understand and integrate different aspects of parasite and pathogen biology and apply this to a real-world infection scenario.

Resit strategy: Resit opportunity will be given to the assessments specified where a resit is available. The resit will have similar format and content as the original assessment, but with substantial revision required and will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 40% (pass mark).

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details of the assessments are in the table below.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that are deemed necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

BIOS211
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
This module is about the parasites and pathogens that normally infect wild animals and plants and which cause disease in
people and livestock. The module will consider the different types of parasites and pathogens; how, when, and where they
infect hosts; the evolution (and co-evolution) of parasites and hosts, and host responses and adaptation to infection. The
module is taught through lectures and workshops, giving students the opportunity to discuss concepts and practice problem solving. The assessment consists of producing a poster (or equivalent) on an example parasite or pathogen and a Briefing Note on a real-world infection scenario.
Educational Aims
1. To develop students’ understanding of the biology of parasites and pathogens and their interaction with hosts, and host responses to infection.

2. To raise students’ awareness of the importance of infection in animal and plant biology and its relevance to disease in people, livestock and crops.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module is about the parasites and pathogens that normally infect wild animals and plants and which cause disease in
people and livestock. The module will consider the different types of parasites and pathogens; how, when, and where they
infect hosts; the evolution (and co-evolution) of parasites and hosts, and host responses and adaptation to infection. The
module is taught through lectures and workshops, giving students the opportunity to discuss concepts and practice
problem solving. The assessment consists of producing a poster (or equivalent) on an example parasite or pathogen and a
Briefing Note on a real-world infection scenario.
Outline Syllabus
This module introduces students to a core feature of animal and plant life – being infected by parasites and pathogens, and that such infection is the normal state, and as such infection is a major evolutionary and ecological force. The module will consider the full range of parasites and pathogens, but will use key examples of very-well studied infections of people and livestock. The main themes of this module are:

1. The different types of micro-parasites (viruses, bacteria, fungi, protozoa) and macro-parasites (platyhelminthes, nematodes, arthropods) as ecto- and endo-parasites,
and their routes of transmission among hosts.

2. The adaptations of parasites and pathogens for an infection lifestyle.

3. The responses of hosts to being infected with parasites and pathogens, and the effects of infection on host fitness.

4. The evolution of parasites, and the co-evolution of parasites and their hosts, and the evolution of parasite virulence.

5. The patterns of distribution of parasites and pathogens in host populations and how this is related to parasite transmission, and to seeking to control infection in host populations.

6. Examples of key infections of people and of livestock and approaches to their control.
Teaching and Learning Methods
The module will be taught via a mixture of lectures and workshops (typically 2 lectures and 1 workshop each week). Learning and teaching throughout this module is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching). Students will have access to online materials including discussion boards, videos, slides and websites (digital literacy). Lectures will be recorded to enable students to access the material remotely (inclusivity). Students will be encouraged to connect their course-based learning with wider reports of relevance, such as continuing human and animal infections across the globe and reports of new therapies and treatments and
to understand this with the broader infection context.

Teaching Method 1
Lectures:
These will cover the core module content.
Attendance Record: Yes

Teaching Method 2
Workshops:
Structured discussion and / or problem-solving workshops will be used to deepen students’ understanding of the topics and to integrate different levels of understanding of infection biology
Attendance Recorded: Yes

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability and organisational skills.

Liverpool Curriculum and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. This module contributes to programmes which are specifically designed to support students for future careers in Biosciences:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists in the field of microbiology and infection biology to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with evidence-based publications of recent clinical and scientific research and application-based sessions/workshops, which highlights how practical skills in microbiology and infection biology research inform biotechnological advancement, therapeutic strategies and management of disease.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Self-directed learning, using interactive resources will allow students to prepare for sessions and gain understanding of practical elements before attending. Resource templates use accessible design schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Negotiated assessment.

Active learning: Continual feedback provided to students by staff, demonstrators and peers alike allow students to assess the extent of their learning and continually develop. Collaborative discussion and interpretation of practical methods and their application to wider science fosters deeper learning. Furthermore, group working in diverse groupings allow students to gain insights into broader perspectives

Authentic assessment: There are two assessment components. The poster or equivalent assessment requires students to lead their own enquiry to select, appraise and concisely communicate specialist subject knowledge in a digestible manner for different target demographics in a medium of their choice. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning and inclusivity. Written scientific assessment, in the form of a briefing note is highly authentic and requires students to understand and integrate different aspects of parasite and pathogen biology and apply this to a real-world infection scenario.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. Workshops involve collaborative groupwork and experimental learning. Learners work as part of a team to plan and carry out complex technical work, under expert supervision. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise. Successfully completing a practical session builds confidence in technical skills.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Learners have access to advanced digital resources, programmes and analytical tools that will assist in the undertaking of data analyses. These are used as part of both lab based practical analyses and independent learning to consolidate practical and theoretical knowledge. Digital technology is embedded into practical teaching with the use of experimental applications, methodologies and practices that learners can explore in their own time. Assessment activity also required students to develop competency with digital technology in order to effectively analyse data, communicate findings and present ideas/concepts.

Global citizenship: Biosciences is a globally connected professional community. Learning and assessment activities embed values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation and use scientific cases of diverse and underrepresented communities, focus on sustainable practices within the lab and field environment, whilst focusing on wider international collaboration in order to achieve goals. There is a strong ethical focus within the school that empowers learners to take personal responsibility for human impact of their actions, with focus on practical related ethics..

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
This module will be assessed by two pieces of coursework. The first assessment (worth 40% of the module) is a poster format (or equivalent) focussed on an example parasite or pathogen from the first half of the module, which the student will choose (which contributes to inclusivity) with staff supervision. This can be a traditional paper poster, or an electronic poster, or a static video installation, or a YouTube-style video, etc. The teaching team will develop these options as this module progresses, and as technology and students’ interests develop.

The second assessment (worth 60%) is in the format of a Briefing Note on a real-world relevant infection scenario, which will require students to understand and integrate different aspects of parasite and pathogen biology and apply this to a real-world setting, which is an authentic assessment.

As mentioned above, both assessments are authentic:
The poster or equivalent assessment requires students to lead their own enquiry to select, appraise and concisely communicate specialist subject knowledge in a digestible manner for different target demographics in a medium of their choice. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning and inclusivity. Written scientific assessment, in the form of a briefing note is highly authentic and requires students to understand and integrate different aspects of parasite and pathogen biology and apply this to a real-world infection scenario.

Formative Feedback will be provided in the weekly workshop sessions and in this way for the assessed material. Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Resit strategy: Resit opportunity will be given to the assessments specified where a resit is available. The resit will have similar format and content as the original assessment, but with substantial revision required and will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 40% (pass mark).

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details of the assessments are in the table below.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that are deemed necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Describe the diversity and biology or parasites and pathogens, their interactions with hosts, and host responses.
 LO2 Critically discuss and evaluate the importance of parasite and pathogens in the biology of host populations and its relevance to controlling infection in people and livestock.
 LO3 Evaluate multiple aspects of infection biology and apply this to real-world settings.

BIOS211
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
This module is about the parasites and pathogens that normally infect wild animals and plants and which cause disease in
people and livestock. The module will consider the different types of parasites and pathogens; how, when, and where they
infect hosts; the evolution (and co-evolution) of parasites and hosts, and host responses and adaptation to infection. The
module is taught through lectures and workshops, giving students the opportunity to discuss concepts and practice problem solving. The assessment consists of producing a poster (or equivalent) on an example parasite or pathogen and a Briefing Note on a real-world infection scenario.
Educational Aims
1. To develop students’ understanding of the biology of parasites and pathogens and their interaction with hosts, and host responses to infection.

2. To raise students’ awareness of the importance of infection in animal and plant biology and its relevance to disease in people, livestock and crops.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module is about the parasites and pathogens that normally infect wild animals and plants and which cause disease in
people and livestock. The module will consider the different types of parasites and pathogens; how, when, and where they
infect hosts; the evolution (and co-evolution) of parasites and hosts, and host responses and adaptation to infection. The
module is taught through lectures and workshops, giving students the opportunity to discuss concepts and practice
problem solving. The assessment consists of producing a poster (or equivalent) on an example parasite or pathogen and a
Briefing Note on a real-world infection scenario.
Outline Syllabus
This module introduces students to a core feature of animal and plant life – being infected by parasites and pathogens, and that such infection is the normal state, and as such infection is a major evolutionary and ecological force. The module will consider the full range of parasites and pathogens, but will use key examples of very-well studied infections of people and livestock. The main themes of this module are:

1. The different types of micro-parasites (viruses, bacteria, fungi, protozoa) and macro-parasites (platyhelminthes, nematodes, arthropods) as ecto- and endo-parasites,
and their routes of transmission among hosts.

2. The adaptations of parasites and pathogens for an infection lifestyle.

3. The responses of hosts to being infected with parasites and pathogens, and the effects of infection on host fitness.

4. The evolution of parasites, and the co-evolution of parasites and their hosts, and the evolution of parasite virulence.

5. The patterns of distribution of parasites and pathogens in host populations and how this is related to parasite transmission, and to seeking to control infection in host populations.

6. Examples of key infections of people and of livestock and approaches to their control.
Teaching and Learning Methods
The module will be taught via a mixture of lectures and workshops (typically 2 lectures and 1 workshop each week). Learning and teaching throughout this module is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching). Students will have access to online materials including discussion boards, videos, slides and websites (digital literacy). Lectures will be recorded to enable students to access the material remotely (inclusivity). Students will be encouraged to connect their course-based learning with wider reports of relevance, such as continuing human and animal infections across the globe and reports of new therapies and treatments and
to understand this with the broader infection context.

Teaching Method 1
Lectures:
These will cover the core module content.
Attendance Record: Yes

Teaching Method 2
Workshops:
Structured discussion and / or problem-solving workshops will be used to deepen students’ understanding of the topics and to integrate different levels of understanding of infection biology
Attendance Recorded: Yes

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability and organisational skills.

Liverpool Curriculum and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. This module contributes to programmes which are specifically designed to support students for future careers in Biosciences:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists in the field of microbiology and infection biology to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with evidence-based publications of recent clinical and scientific research and application-based sessions/workshops, which highlights how practical skills in microbiology and infection biology research inform biotechnological advancement, therapeutic strategies and management of disease.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Self-directed learning, using interactive resources will allow students to prepare for sessions and gain understanding of practical elements before attending. Resource templates use accessible design schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Negotiated assessment.

Active learning: Continual feedback provided to students by staff, demonstrators and peers alike allow students to assess the extent of their learning and continually develop. Collaborative discussion and interpretation of practical methods and their application to wider science fosters deeper learning. Furthermore, group working in diverse groupings allow students to gain insights into broader perspectives

Authentic assessment: There are two assessment components. The poster or equivalent assessment requires students to lead their own enquiry to select, appraise and concisely communicate specialist subject knowledge in a digestible manner for different target demographics in a medium of their choice. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning and inclusivity. Written scientific assessment, in the form of a briefing note is highly authentic and requires students to understand and integrate different aspects of parasite and pathogen biology and apply this to a real-world infection scenario.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. Workshops involve collaborative groupwork and experimental learning. Learners work as part of a team to plan and carry out complex technical work, under expert supervision. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise. Successfully completing a practical session builds confidence in technical skills.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Learners have access to advanced digital resources, programmes and analytical tools that will assist in the undertaking of data analyses. These are used as part of both lab based practical analyses and independent learning to consolidate practical and theoretical knowledge. Digital technology is embedded into practical teaching with the use of experimental applications, methodologies and practices that learners can explore in their own time. Assessment activity also required students to develop competency with digital technology in order to effectively analyse data, communicate findings and present ideas/concepts.

Global citizenship: Biosciences is a globally connected professional community. Learning and assessment activities embed values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation and use scientific cases of diverse and underrepresented communities, focus on sustainable practices within the lab and field environment, whilst focusing on wider international collaboration in order to achieve goals. There is a strong ethical focus within the school that empowers learners to take personal responsibility for human impact of their actions, with focus on practical related ethics..

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
This module will be assessed by two pieces of coursework. The first assessment (worth 40% of the module) is a poster format (or equivalent) focussed on an example parasite or pathogen from the first half of the module, which the student will choose (which contributes to inclusivity) with staff supervision. This can be a traditional paper poster, or an electronic poster, or a static video installation, or a YouTube-style video, etc. The teaching team will develop these options as this module progresses, and as technology and students’ interests develop.

The second assessment (worth 60%) is in the format of a Briefing Note on a real-world relevant infection scenario, which will require students to understand and integrate different aspects of parasite and pathogen biology and apply this to a real-world setting, which is an authentic assessment.

As mentioned above, both assessments are authentic:
The poster or equivalent assessment requires students to lead their own enquiry to select, appraise and concisely communicate specialist subject knowledge in a digestible manner for different target demographics in a medium of their choice. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning and inclusivity. Written scientific assessment, in the form of a briefing note is highly authentic and requires students to understand and integrate different aspects of parasite and pathogen biology and apply this to a real-world infection scenario.

Formative Feedback will be provided in the weekly workshop sessions and in this way for the assessed material. Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Resit strategy: Resit opportunity will be given to the assessments specified where a resit is available. The resit will have similar format and content as the original assessment, but with substantial revision required and will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 40% (pass mark).

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details of the assessments are in the table below.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that are deemed necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
